column1: After several failed attempts in previous sessions
column2: the California legislature passed a bill authorizing the portion of Los Angeles County south of Coyote Creek to hold a referendum on whether to remain part of Los Angeles County or to secede and form a new county to be named “Orange” as directed by the legislature. Such referendum required a 2/3 vote for secession to take place
column3: and subsequently on June 4
column5: the residents south of Coyote Creek voted 2
column6: 509 to 500 in favor of secession. After such referendum
column7: Los Angeles County filed three lawsuits in the courts to stall and stop the secession from occurring
column8: but such attempts were futile. On July 17
column10: a second referendum was held south of the Coyote Creek to determine if the county seat of the to-be county to be in either Anaheim or Santa Ana
column11: along with an election for every county officer. In the end
column12: Santa Ana defeated Anaheim in such referendum.  With the referendum taken place
column13: the County of Orange was officially incorporated on August 1
column15: as prescribed by state law. Since the date of the incorporation of the county
column16: the only geographical changes to have occurred which affected Orange County was when the County and Los Angeles County agreed to trade land around Coyote Creek to adjust the border of the two counties to conform with city blocks.

column1: The county is said to have been named for the citrus fruit in an attempt to promote immigration by suggesting a semi-tropical paradise – a place where anything could grow.

The completion of Interstate 5 in 1954 helped make Orange County a bedroom community for many who moved to Southern California to work in aerospace and manufacturing. Orange County received a further boost in 1955 with the opening of Disneyland.

an investment fund meltdown led to the criminal prosecution of treasurer Robert Citron. The county lost at least $1.5 billion through high-risk investments in bonds. The loss was blamed on derivatives by some media reports. On December 6

These conflicts have regarded issues such as construction of new toll roads and the repurposing of a decommissioned air base. El Toro Marine Corps Air Station was designated by a voter measure in 1994 to be developed into an international airport to complement the existing John Wayne Airport. But subsequent voter initiatives and court actions have caused the airport plan to be permanently shelved. Instead

column1: During most of the 20th century and up until 2016
column2: Orange County was known for its political conservatism and for being a bastion for the Republican Party
column3: with a 2005 academic study listing three Orange County cities as among America's 25 most conservative. However
column4: the county's changing demographics have coincided with a shift in political alignments. In 2016
column5: Hillary Clinton became the first Democrat since 1936 to carry Orange County in a presidential election and in the 2018 midterm elections the Democratic Party gained control of every Congressional seat in the county. Although Democrats control all congressional districts in Orange County
column6: Republicans maintained a lead in voter registration numbers
column7: although it shrunk to less than a percentage point as of February 10
column9: as compared with over 10% on February 10
column10: 2013. The number of registered Democrats surpassed the number of registered Republicans in the county in August 2019. As the number of Democrats increased
column11: the number of voters not aligned with a political party increased to comprise 27.4% of the county's voters in 2019. Republicans hold a 4-1 majority on the county Board of Supervisors. Seven out of the 12 state legislators from Orange County are also Republicans.

column1: Orange County has long been known as a Republican stronghold and has consistently sent Republican representatives to the state and federal legislatures — so strongly so
column2: that Ronald Reagan described it as the place that "all the good Republicans go to die."  Republican majorities in Orange County helped deliver California's electoral votes to Republican nominees Richard Nixon in 1960
column4: and 1972; Gerald Ford in 1976; Reagan in 1980 and 1984; and George H. W. Bush in 1988. It was one of five counties in the state that voted for Barry Goldwater in 1964.

column1: In 1936 Orange County gave Franklin D. Roosevelt a majority of its presidential vote. The Republican nominee won Orange County in the next 19 presidential elections
column2: until Hillary Clinton won the county with a majority in 2016.The Republican margin began to narrow in the 1990s and 2000s as the state trended Democratic until the mid to late 2010s when it voted for the Democratic Party in 2016 and the Democratic Party managed to gain all seven Congressional districts in the county
column3: including all four districts anchored in the county
column4: in the 2018. This prompted media outlets to declare Orange County's Republican leanings "dead"

column1: The county is featured prominently in Lisa McGirr's book Suburban Warriors: The Origins of the New American Right. She argues that its conservative political orientation in the 20th century owed much to its settlement by farmers from the Great Plains
column2: who reacted strongly to communist sympathies
column3: the civil rights movement
column4: and the turmoil of the 1960s in nearby Los Angeles — across the "Orange Curtain".

column2: Orange County was one of California's leading Republican voting blocs and a subculture of residents with "Middle American" values that emphasized capitalist religious morality in contrast to West coast liberalism.

column1: Orange County has many Republican voters from culturally conservative Asian-American
column2: Middle Eastern and Latino immigrant groups. The large Vietnamese-American communities in Garden Grove and Westminster are predominantly Republican; Vietnamese Americans registered Republicans outnumber those registered as Democrats
column4: while as of 2017 that figure is 42% to 36%. Republican Assemblyman Van Tran was the first Vietnamese-American elected to a state legislature and joined with Texan Hubert Vo as the highest-ranking elected Vietnamese-American in the United States until the 2008 election of Joseph Cao in Louisiana's 2nd congressional district. In the 2007 special election for the vacant county supervisor seat following Democrat Lou Correa's election to the state senate
column5: two Vietnamese-American Republican candidates topped the list of 10 candidates
column6: separated from each other by only seven votes
column7: making the Orange County Board of Supervisors entirely Republican; Correa is first of only two Democrats to have served on the Board since 1987 and only the fifth since 1963.

column6: Epicor
column7: and Sun Healthcare Group. Other Fortune 1000 companies in Orange County include Beckman Coulter in Brea

column11: and in-flight product manufacturer Panasonic Avionics Corporation. Also

column25: and Safmarine. Wet Seal is headquartered in Lake Forest. PacSun is headquartered in Anaheim. Restaurants such as Taco Bell

column3: Knotts Berry Farm gets about 7 million visitors annually and is located in the city of Buena Park. The Anaheim Convention Center holds many major conventions throughout the year. Resorts within the Beach Cities receive visitors throughout the year due to their close proximity to the beach

column7: and Top Chef chef Amar Santana opened a branch of Charlie Palmer (closed 2015)

column1: Orange County is the home of many colleges and universities
Some institutions not based in Orange County operate satellite campuses
column2: including the University of Southern California
column3: National University
column4: Pepperdine University
column5: and Springfield College.

column1: The Orange County Department of Education oversees 28 school districts.
Orange County is served by media in Los Angeles
column2: including its TV and radio stations. Two television stations—KOCE-TV
column3: the main PBS station in the Southland and KDOC-TV
column4: an independent—are located in Orange County.

column1: There are a few radio stations that are actually located in Orange County. KYLA 92.7 FM has a Christian format. KSBR 88.5 FM airs a jazz music format branded as "Jazz-FM" along with news programming. KUCI 88.9 FM is a free form college radio station that broadcasts from UC Irvine. KWIZ 96.7 FM
column3: airs a regional Mexican music format branded as "La Rockola 96.7". KWVE-FM 107.9 is owned by the Calvary Chapel of Costa Mesa. KWVE-FM is also the primary Emergency Alert System station for the county. The Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim also own and operate a sports-only radio station from Orange
column4: KLAA. KX 93.5 FM broadcasts out of Laguna Beach and features an eclectic mix of mostly alternative rock.

column1: County-wide politics and government coverage is primarily provided by The Orange County Register and Voice of OC. OC Weekly is an alternative weekly publication
column2: and Excélsior is a Spanish-language newspaper. A few communities are served by the Los Angeles Times' publication of the Daily Pilot. Orange Coast was established in 1974 and is the oldest continuously published lifestyle magazine in the region. OC Music Magazine is also based out of Orange County
column3: serving local musicians and artists.

column1: Transit in Orange County is offered primarily by the Orange County Transportation Authority. The American Public Transportation Association (APTA) cited OCTA as the best large public transportation system in the United States for 2005. OCTA manages the county's bus network and funds the construction and maintenance of local streets
column3: and freeways; regulates taxicab services; maintains express toll lanes through the median of California State Route 91; and works with Southern California's Metrolink to provide commuter rail service along three lines: the Orange County Line
column4: the 91 Line
column5: and the Inland Empire-Orange County Line.

column1: Ground transportation in Orange County relies heavily on three major interstate highways: the Santa Ana Freeway (I-5)
column2: the San Diego Freeway (I-405 and I-5 south of Irvine)
column3: and the San Gabriel River Freeway (I-605)
column4: which briefly passes through northwestern Orange County. The other freeways in the county are state highways
column5: and include the Riverside and Artesia Freeway (SR 91) and the Garden Grove Freeway (SR 22) running east–west
column6: and the Orange Freeway (SR 57)
column7: the Costa Mesa Freeway (SR 55)
column9: the San Joaquin Transportation Corridor (SR 73)
column11: SR 133
column13: and the Foothill Transportation Corridor (SR 241) running north–south. Minor stub freeways include the Richard M. Nixon Freeway (SR 90)
column15: and the southern terminus of Pacific Coast Highway (SR 1). There are no U.S. Highways in Orange County
column16: though two existed in the county until the mid-1960s: 91 and 101. US 91 went through what is now the state route of the same number
column17: and US 101 was replaced by Interstate 5. SR 1 was once a bypass of US 101 (Route 101A).

column3: running along most major streets
column4: and accounts for 210
column5: 000 boardings a day. The fleet of 817 buses is gradually being replaced by CNG (Compressed natural gas)-powered vehicles
column6: which already represent over 40% of the total fleet. Service is operated by OCTA employees and First Transit under contract. OCTA operates one bus rapid transit service
column7: Bravo
column9: OCTA offers paratransit service for the disabled

column2: Metrolink has operated three commuter rail lines through Orange County
column3: and has also maintained Rail-to-Rail service with parallel Amtrak service. On a typical weekday
column4: over 40 trains run along the Orange County Line
column5: the 91 Line and the Inland Empire-Orange County Line. Along with Metrolink riders on parallel Amtrak lines
column6: these lines generate approximately 15
column7: 000 boardings per weekday. Metrolink also began offering weekend service on the Orange County Line and the Inland Empire-Orange County line in the summer of 2006. As ridership has steadily increased in the region
column8: new stations have opened at Anaheim Canyon
column9: Buena Park
column11: and Laguna Niguel/Mission Viejo. Plans for a future station in Placentia are underway and is expected to be completed by 2020.

column4: and Santa Fe Railroad and later Amtrak
column5: has operated the Pacific Surfliner regional passenger train route (previously named the San Diegan until 2000) through Orange County. The route includes stops at eight stations in Orange County including
column6: in northbound order

column1: The Santa Ana/Garden Grove Fixed Guideway Project plans a streetcar line connecting Downtown Santa Ana to the Depot at Santa Ana has completed the environmental document and is entering the design phase. OCTA has also proposed connecting the two systems via Harbor Boulevard and the West Santa Ana Branch corridor. Plans for a streetcar for Harbor Boulevard in Fullerton
column3: and Garden Grove — the Anaheim Rapid Connection — were shelved in 2018.

column1: A car and passenger ferry service
column3: comprising three ferries running every five minutes
column4: operates within Newport Harbor between Balboa Peninsula and Balboa Island in Newport Beach.  The Catalina Flyer connects the Balboa Peninsula to Avalon with daily round-trip passage through about nine months of the year.  The Catalina Express connects Dana Point to Avalon (with departures from two greater Long Beach ports also connecting to Two Harbors).

column1: Orange County's only major airport is John Wayne Airport; its abbreviation (SNA) refers to Santa Ana
column2: the closest large town in the early 20th century. The airport is located in unincorporated territory surrounded by Newport Beach
column3: Costa Mesa
column4: and Irvine. On destination monitors with flights to SNA
column5: the airport is usually described as "Orange County
column6: CA". In 2014
column7: its Thomas F. Riley Terminal handled over 9 million passengers annually and as of 2019
column8: seven airline brands provide scheduled service.

column1: The area's warm Mediterranean climate and 42 miles (68 km) of year-round beaches attract millions of tourists annually. Huntington Beach is a hot spot for sunbathing and surfing; nicknamed "Surf City
column3: it is home to many surfing competitions. "The Wedge"
column4: at the tip of The Balboa Peninsula in Newport Beach
column5: is one of the most famous body surfing spots in the world. Southern California surf culture is prominent in Orange County's beach cities. Another one of these beach cities being Laguna Beach
column6: just south of Newport Beach. A few popular beaches include A Thousand Steps on 9th Street
column7: Main Street Beach
column8: and The Montage. Other "local" beaches that are worth a visit are Tablerock Beach and West Street Beach
column9: both located in South Laguna Beach.

column1: Other tourist destinations include the theme parks Disneyland and Disney California Adventure Park in Anaheim and Knott's Berry Farm in Buena Park. Since the 2011 closure of Wild Rivers in Irvine
column2: the county is home to just one water park: Soak City in Buena Park. The Anaheim Convention Center is the largest such facility on the West Coast. The old town area in the City of Orange (the traffic circle at the middle of Chapman Ave. at Glassell) still maintains its 1950s image
column3: and appeared in the movie That Thing You Do!.

column1: Little Saigon is another tourist destination
column2: home to the largest concentration of Vietnamese people outside Vietnam. There are also sizable Taiwanese
column3: Chinese
column4: and Korean communities
column5: particularly in western Orange County. This is evident in several Asian-influenced shopping centers in Asian American hubs like Irvine. Popular food festival 626 Night Market has a location at OC Fair & Event Center in Costa Mesa and is a popular attraction for Asian and fusion food
column6: as well as an Art Walk and live entertainment.Historical points of interest include Mission San Juan Capistrano
column7: the renowned destination of migrating swallows. The Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum is in Yorba Linda and the Richard Nixon Birthplace
column8: on the grounds of the Library
column9: is a National Historic Landmark. John Wayne's yacht
column10: the Wild Goose or USS YMS-328
column11: is in Newport Beach. Other notable structures include the home of Madame Helena Modjeska
column12: in Modjeska Canyon on Santiago Creek; Ronald Reagan Federal Building and Courthouse in Santa Ana
column13: the largest building in the county; the historic Balboa Pavilion in Newport Beach; and the Huntington Beach Pier. The county has nationally known centers of worship
column14: such as Crystal Cathedral in Garden Grove
column15: the largest house of worship in California; Saddleback Church in Lake Forest
column16: one of the largest churches in the United States; and the Calvary Chapel.

column1: The Major League Baseball team in Orange County is the Los Angeles Angels.  The team won the World Series under manager Mike Scioscia in 2002.  In 2005
column2: new owner Arte Moreno wanted to change the name to "Los Angeles Angels" in order to better tap into the Los Angeles media market
column3: the second largest in the country. However
column4: the standing agreement with the city of Anaheim demanded that they have "Anaheim" in the name
column5: so they became the Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim. This name change was hotly disputed by the city of Anaheim
column6: but the change stood and still stands today
column7: which prompted a lawsuit by the city of Anaheim against Arte Moreno

column1: The county's National Hockey League team
column3: won the 2007 Stanley Cup beating the Ottawa Senators.  They also came close to winning the 2003 Stanley Cup finals after losing in Game 7 against the New Jersey Devils.

column2: the only PGA Champions Tour event in the area
column3: is held each March at The Newport Beach Country Club.  Past champions include Fred Couples (2010)
column4: Hale Irwin (1998 and 2002)
column5: Nick Price (2011)
column6: Bernhard Langer (2008) and Jay Haas (2007).  The tournament benefits the Hoag Hospital Foundation and has raised over $16 million in its first 16 years.

column1: Orange County SC is a United Soccer League team and are the only professional soccer club in Orange County. The team's first season was in 2011 and it was successful as Charlie Naimo's team made it to the quarter-finals of the playoffs. With home games played at Championship Soccer Stadium in Orange County Great Park the team looks to grow in the Orange County community and reach continued success. Former and current Orange County SC players include Richard Chaplow
column3: Maykel Galindo
column4: Carlos Borja
column5: and goalkeeper Amir Abedzadeh.

column1: The National Football League left the county when the Los Angeles Rams relocated to St. Louis in 1995. They relocated back to Southern California in January 2016.
